Nitrogen-doped carbon confined cobalt nanoparticles (Co-N-C) were synthesized through multi-step pyrolysis method. The Co-N-C samples exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile, of which the yield can be as high as 93.7% within 2.5 min with outstanding stability and recyclability. The catalytic performance may be primarily ascribed to the richness in nitrogen and cobalt in the form of the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP), i.e. the Co ion acts as a Lewis acid site to activate the carbonyl oxygen of benzaldehyde molecules, and nitrogen in carbon acts as a Lewis base site to activate the methylene hydrogen of malononitrile. From the perspective of intrinsic catalytic activity, variations in catalytic properties are attributed to the electron density distribution on the surface of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Nitrogen-doped carbon confined cobalt nanoparticles as the acid-base bifunctional catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance for the Knoevenagel reaction between benzaldehyde and malononitrile, which may be primarily ascribed to the highest contents of nitrogen and Cobalt in the form of the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP) from Coδ+ of Co nanoparticles and Nδ− of nitrogen-contained species. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-doped carbon Cobalt-based catalyst Knoevenagel reaction Solid frustrated Lewis pair Melamine Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Catalysts play a vital role in most chemical processes and are involved in many chemical engineering fields such as the energy chemical industry, biomedicine, and environmental protection [1–3]. Today, the chemical industry is urged to upgrade its structure, and the development of catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability is extremely important for the green and low-carbon chemical industry [4,5]. The Knoevenagel condensation reaction of carbonyl groups (in aldehydes or ketones) and active methylene groups is one important method to manufacture α and β-unsaturated compounds, in which carbon-carbon double bonds are formed. Formation of CC double bonds is crucial in the synthesis of agrochemicals, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, biologically significant heterocyclic compounds and many other fine chemicals [6–8]. Traditionally, the Knoevenagel condensation is catalyzed by homogeneous bases, such as primary amines, secondary amines, piperidines, pyridines, basic hydroxyl groups and Lewis-acid metal ion (for example, Zn2+) [9,10]. These homogeneous catalytic systems are costly in terms of time and labor, and require high-temperature conditions to function, but the selectivity is still not high enough. Meanwhile, the use of toxic solvents and recycle of homogeneous catalysts add more to the budget. From the perspective of recycling and sustainable development, more and more attention has been paid to heterogeneous catalysts under mild conditions for Knoevenagel condensation. For instance, zeolite [11], metal-organic frameworks [12], covalent organic framework [9], graphene [13] have been used to catalyze the reaction. But so far, such issues persist as high cost, high reaction temperature, toxic solvent, low selectivity, and long reaction time. Boronat et al. proposed that although both base and acid sites can catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction, bifunctional catalysts with sufficient acid-base pairs are more active than pure acid or base catalysts [14]. The bifunctional acid-base supported material seems to be a promising catalyst due to its ability to simultaneously activate both nucleophiles and electrophiles with synergistic interactions [15,16]. MOF [12], achiral silanols and grafted chiral amines on mesoporous silica, amine-functionalized material prepared by grafting (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES) onto SBA-15 support (SBA-15-NH2) [17] and La2O2CO3-TiO2 mixed oxide [18] are also found to result in acid-base synergistic catalysis of Knoevenagel reaction. Carbon materials are widely used as catalyst supports due to their porosity, large specific surface area and resistance to corrosion [19]. However, when the carbon material is used as support, leaching or agglomeration of metal active components often occur due to the weak binding between metal and carbon, and the stability of the catalyst is compromised [20]. Heteroatom (such as boron, sulfur, phosphorus, and nitrogen) doping can significantly change the composition of carbon materials and improve the physical and chemical properties of the material surface [21]. Among many heteroatoms, the size of nitrogen is the closest to carbon. When nitrogen atoms are doped onto the surface of a carbon material, distortions and defects take place, which strengthen the binding between the support and the active metal component by metal-nitrogen coordination effect, and thus improve catalytic stability and activity [20,22–24] On the other hand, the lone electron pair of nitrogen atom can occupy specific empty orbits in the metal and thus change the electron density distribution(or the valence state of the metal). This also enhances stability and activity [25]. Furthermore, the lone electron pair in the nitrogen atom can also act as a Lewis base to accelerate the reaction rate. Therefore, introducing nitrogen atoms or nitrogen-containing functional groups into the carbon material is a good way to solve the above-mentioned catalytic problems. Nitrogen-doped carbon supported metal catalysts have numerous applications in the Knoevenagel reaction. Huang and co-workers [26] used amino-functionalized metal-organic framework UIO-66-NH2 as raw material to synthesize a nitrogen-rich carbon-ZrO2 composite material (CN-ZrO2), which can effectively catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Chowhan and co-workers [19] synthesized an ultrafine Pd-based nanocatalyst containing N-doped carbon structures (Pd@NC). The Pd@NC nanocatalyst showed excellent activity for base-free Knoevenagel condensation, due to the metal-support interaction (MSI) between metallic palladium and pyridinic-N doped carbon. Huang and co-workers [27], developed a N-doped oriented carbon structure composite material with hierarchical pores and ultrafine Pd nanoclusters. This refined core-shell nanostructure enables good catalytic activity, excellent structural stability and leaching/aggregation resistance for the one-pot condensation/hydrogenation reaction of a series of substituted aromatic aldehydes. Horimoto et al. reported that in the presence of BCl3 vapor, boron-containing carbon nitrogen (BCN) materials prepared by heat treatment of nitrogen-containing polymer polyacrylonitrile (PAN) showed good catalytic activity for Knoevenagel reaction and revealed that the content of BNC-type nitrogen is responsible for improving the catalytic activity [28]. However, in these studies, noble metal catalysts are often used, to which the improvement of reaction performance is mostly attributed. At the same time, the interaction between the metal and the support is not specified in detail, and the reaction mechanism is not clear. In this paper, nitrogen-doped carbon-supported cobalt particles (Co-N-C) were prepared by multi-step pyrolysis after mixing three different nitrogen sources with cobalt salts in a one-pot method. Various techniques were used to determine the effect of nitrogen-containing carbon sources on catalyst performance. The activity of these catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and malononitrile was investigated. To explore the substrate scope and versatility of aldehydes, the catalytic activity of carbonyl compounds with different substitutions was investigated under optimized conditions. We also discussed the working mechanism for Co-N-C catalysts. This work may provide the reference for the related heterogeneous acid-base catalytic reactions, especially in the design of steric bifunctional catalysts with Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All reagents are ready to use without purification. CoCl2·6H2O and ethanol were purchased from Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd., dicyandiamide (DCD), malononitrile, and benzaldehyde were purchased from Shanghai Macleans Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., melamine (MLM) was purchased from Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute, chitosan (CTS) was purchased from Chengdu West Asia Chemical Co., Ltd., and distilled water was purchased from Qingdao Jingke Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of Co-N-C and Co-N-C-H catalysts 2.2.1.1 Synthesis of Co-MLM, Co-DCD and Co-CTS Melamine (MLM, 6 g) was dissolved in 0.25 mol/L CoCl2·6H2O aqueous solution (100 mL) and stirred in an oil bath at 80 °C for at least 12 h, until the water in the solution evaporated completely. The solid obtained was washed 3 times with distilled water and dried overnight at 60 °C to obtain solid Co-MLM samples. When other nitrogen-containing carbon sources (chitosan, CTS and dicyandiamide, DCD), are used instead of MLM following the same procedure, we obtain Co-DCD and Co-CTS samples. 2.2.1.2 Preparation of Co-N-C catalysts The solid product was placed in a quartz boat in a tube furnace filled with argon. In Ar atmosphere, the sample was first heated from room temperature to 350 °C, and pyrolyzed under that temperature for 3 h, then heated to 600 °C for 3 h of pyrolysis; the last stage of pyrolysis was at 900 °C for 3 h. The rate of temperature rising was always 3 °C/min during each heating phase. The sample was then cooled to room temperature naturally. The obtained black solids were washed several times with distilled water and ethanol, subsequently dried at 60 °C overnight. The final products are named Co-N-C-MLM, Co-N-C-CTS, and Co-N-C-DCD, respectively. 2.2.1.3 Preparation of Co-N-C-H catalysts The products from pyrolysis could first be pickled with 1 mol/L HCl at 120 °C for 12 h, before being washed with distilled water and ethanol and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. In this way, we obtain samples coined Con-N-C-MLM-H, Con-N-C-CTS-H and, Con-N-C-DCD-H. 2.2.2 Synthesis of N-C-CTS, N-C-MLM, N-C-DCD catalysts CTS was placed in a porcelain boat in a vacuum tube furnace and processed with the same procedure as in 2.2.1. The resulting catalyst is called N-C-CTS. Samples N-C-MLM and N-C-DCD are produced similarly, with their corresponding nitrogenous carbon agent. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Co-C catalyst Glucose(GLC, 6 g) was dissolved in 0.25 mol/L CoCl2·6H2O aqueous solution (100 mL) and stirred in an oil bath at 80 °C for at least 12 h, until water in the solution evaporated completely. The solid obtained was washed 3 times with distilled water and dried overnight at 60 °C to obtain solid Co-GLC samples. Co-GLC was placed in a porcelain boat in a vacuum tube furnace and followed by the same pyrolysis procedure as in 2.2.1. The resulting catalyst is called Co-C. 2.2.4 Synthesis of C-GLC catalyst GLC was placed in a porcelain boat in a vacuum tube furnace and processed with the same procedure as in 2.2.1. The resulting catalyst is called C-GLC. 2.2.5 Synthesis of Co-N-C-MLM-A catalyst Melamine (MLM, 6 g) was dissolved in 0.25 mol/L CoCl2·6H2O aqueous solution (100 mL) and stirred in an oil bath at 80 °C for at least 12 h, until the water in the solution evaporated completely. The solid obtained was washed 3 times with distilled water and dried overnight at 60 °C to obtain solid Co-MLM samples. The solid product was placed in a quartz boat in a tube furnace filled with argon. In Ar atmosphere, the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C, and pyrolyzed under that temperature for 3 h. The rate of temperature rising was always 3 °C /min during each heating phase. The sample was then cooled to room temperature naturally. The obtained black solids were washed several times with distilled water and ethanol, subsequently dried at 60 °C overnight. The resulting catalyst is called Co-N-C-MLM-A. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The surface area and pore size of the samples were obtained from N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K with an ASAP2460 instrument (McMuritic (Shanghai) Instrument Co., Ltd.). Before measurement, the samples were degassed at 180 °C for 12 h. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of catalysts were recorded on a Rigaku Utima IV X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation). The surface topography of catalysts was investigated by an APREO scanning electron microscope (FEI, Apreo S HiVac) and a Transmission Electron Microscope (FEI, Tecnai G2 F20). Elemental analysis were performed on the ICP pe8000 inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (Agilent) ICP-AES and Organic element analyzer (VARIO EL cube). The content of elemental Co is determined by ICP-AES test and the content of elemental O is determined by elemental analysis. The formula for calculating the content of element C is as follows: C ( wt . % ) = C ( wt . % ) EA / ( C ( wt . % ) EA + H ( wt . % ) EA + N ( wt . % ) EA + S ( wt . % ) EA ) 1 − Co ( wt . % ) − O ( wt . % ) where C(wt.%)EA is the amount of C measured by elemental analysis; H(wt.%)EA is the amount of H measured by elemental analysis; N(wt.%)EA is the amount of N measured by elemental analysis; S(wt.%)EA is the amount of S measured by elemental analysis. Change the corresponding carry-over values when calculating N and H elemental content. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a K-alpha 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Technology Co., Ltd.). NH3-TPD was detected on a Sentron TP-5080D mass spectrometer Hyde Decra. The specific operation steps are shown here. (1) A certain mass of sample was loaded into a U-tube, heated to 900 °C in a protective atmosphere, constant temperature for 1 h, and then reduced to room temperature (50 °C); (2) Injected NH3 mixture to saturation at room temperature (50 °C); (3) Then purged for 2 h at room temperature to remove the physically adsorbed protective gas; (4) Finally, chemical desorption was carried out by ramping up to 900 °C at 10 °C/min and then waiting for 30 min. Pyridine-FTIR was detected using a tensor 27 Fourier infrared spectrometer from Bruker. The samples were sealed in the in-situ cell of the infrared spectrometer after being pressed from the support sheet, evacuated to 10−3 Pa at 400 °C and kept for 1 h to desorb the gas molecules on the sample surface, and cooled to room temperature to collect the background. Pyridine vapor was introduced into the in-situ cell, equilibrated for 30 min, warmed up to 350 °C, evacuated to 10−3 Pa again, kept at 10−3 Pa for 30 min, cooled down to room temperature, and then scanned in the wave number range of 1400–1700 cm−1, and the infrared spectral spectrum of the pyridine adsorption at 350 °C was recorded. Raman experiments were conducted on a LABRAMHR spectrometer (France) using the green line of an argon laser (λ = 514.5 nm) as the excitation source. The hammett indicator method was chosen for the basic strength characterization of the catalysts, and the corresponding basic strength and color changes for each indicator are listed in Table 1 . Each indicator was dissolved in ethanol and prepared as a 1% solution. After dissolving each indicator in ethanol and preparing a 1% solution, 1 mL was taken and diluted to 10 mL with methanol, and then 0.3 g of catalyst was added, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The color change of the mixture was observed, and the range of basic strength of each sample was determined one by one. The total base content of the catalyst was determined by a potentiometric titrator. Benzoic acid-ethanol solution (0.02 mmol/L) was configured in advance. Catalyst (0.1 g) was added to 50 mL of deionized water and stired for about 2 h, titrated with benzoic acid solution until a potential jump occured in the mixture, recorded the volume of benzoic acid solution consumed, and then calculated the amount of base. 2.4 Knoevenagel condensation 20 mmol of benzaldehyde and malononitrile was dissolved in a conical flask. The solution was stirred evenly in a water bath at 30 °C, before a catalyst was added. At the end of the reaction, the cured product was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol, and 1 mmol n-dodecane was added as the internal standard. The reaction mixture was analyzed by a Thermo Fisher GC–MS (Trace GC Ultra-ITQ 1100 ) equipped with Thermo TR-Wax MD column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). Quantitative data of area and concentration were obtained from GC and calculated according to the internal standard (n-dodecane). The conversion of benzaldehyde is equal to (C0 − Ct )/ C0 × 100%, where C 0 is the initial concentration of benzaldehyde and Ct is the concentration of benzaldehyde at time t. The selectivity is equal to Pt /(C0 − C t ) × 100%, where Pt is the concentration of product at time t. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization Table 2 shows the results of ICP-AES and elemental analysis of Co-N-C. When MLM and DCD are used as the nitrogen-containing carbon source, the content of cobalt in the catalyst is higher than that when CTS is used. For the CTS-based samples, cobalt is almost washed out in the form of ions during the preparation of Co-N-C-CTS, because the interaction between cobalt ion and CTS is weak. After pickling, the content of Co in all three catalysts (Co-N-C-MLM-H, Co-N-C-DCD-H, Co-N-C-CTS-H) drops sharply, and the content of carbon increases significantly. Compared with DCD and CTS samples, the nitrogen and oxygen contents of the MLM samples hardly change before and after pickling, which indicates that the nitrogen doped carbon prepared by MLM has better acid washing resistance. The Co (48.57 wt.%) and N (5.43 wt.%) content in the Co-N-C-MLM catalysts was significantly higher than the Co (32.66 wt.%) and N (0.92 wt.%) content in the Co-N-C-MLM-A catalysts. Furthermore, compared the results of Co-N-C-MLM and Co-N-C-MLM-A, it can be seen that the nitrogen and cobalt contents of multi-step pyrolysis are higher than those of one-step pyrolysis. The phase structure of the catalysts was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peak near 51° may be attributed to Co2O3 [29]. And the peaks at 44° and 76° correspond to the (111) and (220) planes of face-centered cubic cobalt phase [29]. The wider diffraction peak at 2θ = 25° may be ascribed to the (002) crystal plane of graphitized carbon (PDF# is 50-0927) [30]. For Co-N-C catalysts synthesized from MLM or DCD, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Co (including metal Co and Co2O3) are obvious. After acid pickling, the peak intensity decreases significantly (especially for Co2O3), due to loss of the element by acid treatment. In addition, the intensity of the characteristic peaks of graphite carbon is enhanced after acid treatment, because most of the cobalt nanoparticles adsorbed on graphite surface have been removed by acid pickling exposing the surface of graphite. When CTS is used as the nitrogen-containing carbon source, the characteristic peaks of cobalt species are attenuated, which may be due to low cobalt content on the surface. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the Co-N-C composites are shown in Fig. 2 . All samples show typical type IV isotherms with H4 type hysteresis loops, indicating that the synthesized catalysts have large porosity [31,32]. It can be seen from Table 3 that the average pore size of the material is around 3.5 nm [33–35], and the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the catalysts all increase after acid treatment. Among all, the catalyst synthesized with chitosan as precursor has the highest specific surface area, but more than 70% of the specific surface area is contributed by micropores. The reason may be that chitosan tends to decompose during the pyrolysis process into CO2, H2O and other gases, making it easier for the final nitrogen-doped carbon material to form more porous structures. In contrast, Co-N-C-DCD, Co-N-C-DCD-H, Co-N-C-MLM and Co-N-C-MLM-H have smaller specific surface area, but more mesoporous specific surface area than Co-N-C-CTS and Co-N-C-CTS-H. Figs. 3–5 present the SEM characterization of Co-N-C catalysts synthesized from different nitrogen-containing carbon sources. Fig. 6 shows the TEM characterization path of the Co-N-C-MLM catalyst. It can be seen from Fig. 3 that the morphology of the Co-N-C-MLM is a tubular structure with an average diameter of 1 μm. The surface of the acid-washed Co-N-C-MLM-H is rougher than that of Co-N-C-MLM. TEM characterization of Co-N-C-MLM also showed that the material has a tubular morphology (Fig. 6A and B). Fig. 6C shows a typical metallic Co with crystal lattices of 0.21 nm, which is assigned to the (111) interplanar spacing of metallic Co. The lattice spacing outside of the graphite carbon is 0.34 nm, which can be assigned to C(200). In addition, the morphology of the Co-N-C-DCD is vesicular with a diameter of about 2 μm, and the vesicles have a relatively smooth surface (Fig. 4A and B). After pickling, the smooth vesicles are destroyed and the carbon skeleton is fully exposed (Fig. 4C and D). However, Co-N-C-CTS is an irregularly shaped sheet-like structure. After pickling, the catalyst surface becomes wrinkled and rough (Fig. 5). This is because that acid washing has removed the cobalt nanoparticles covering the surface of the graphite, which appears rough after the treatment. Meanwhile the acid can bring forth more pores and therefore enlarge the BET surface area and porous volume of the catalyst (Fig. 2 and Table 3) [36]. In addition, combined with the ICP-AES analysis results (Table 2), it is clear that there is little cobalt in the acid-treated samples. The reduced intensity of the peaks associated with cobalt in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1) suggests that the Co nanoparticles are removed, contributing to the formation of a large number of pores in the carbon matrix, which also results in a larger specific surface area for Co-N-C-MLM-H than for Co-N-C-MLM. Fig. 7 and figures S1 and S2 exhibit the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the Co-N-C-MLM, Co-N-C-DCD, and Co-N-C-CTS samples. According to the full spectra, Co-N-C-MLM, Co-N-C-MLM-H, Co-N-C-DCD, Co-N-C-DCD-H, and Co-N-C-CTS all contain the four elements: Co, N, O and C. But Co-N-C-CTS-H only contains N, O, and C. Its Co content is only 0.17% (as shown in Table 2). Based on the literature [29,37–40], it can be seen that the two peaks at 778.7 eV and 793.9 eV correspond to Co0 in Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, the two at 780.6 eV and 795.8 eV correspond to Co-O in Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 and those at 782.6 eV and 797.8 eV correspond to Co-N in Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. While the satellite peaks at 786.2 eV and 801.4 eV are mainly derived from Co-O in Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2. The N species in each sample mainly include pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and Co-N. And the electronic binding energies of pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphic N and Co-N species are located at 398.6 eV, 400.4 eV, 401.4 eV, 399.2 eV, respectively [41]. Table 4 shows the proportions of Co and N species in the Co-N-C samples, which were obtained from the area of XPS spectrum. For the samples synthesized from MLM and DCD, the content of Co-O species in the acid-washed catalyst is significantly reduced, while the relative content of Co0 species is much increased, which is inconsistent with the result of XRD characterization. Considering that only the surface with a depth less than 10 nm from the surface can be detected by XPS, but XRD can penetrate the whole crystal material for detection, it can be speculated that part of Co0 may be removed by acid, or strongly coordinated with nitrogen in carbon, which is difficult to be oxidized with dioxygen in atmospheric temperature or. Therefore, the Co-N content of samples synthesized from melamine and dicyandiamide changes little before and after acid pickling, indicating that the CoN bond is more stable than Co-O, due to the strong coordination effect between cobalt and nitrogen. This effect may also improve the stability of the catalyst. For N species, the content of Co-N and pyridine nitrogen species of the material synthesized with melamine is much higher than that of materials synthesized from other nitrogen sources. However, almost no cobalt species can be detected in Co-N-C-CTS-H, which may be related to the low cobalt loading in Co-N-C-CTS and the difficulty of forming acid-resistant nitrogen species when chitosan decomposes (as shown in Table 2). Further information of the structural and electronic properties of the materials can be obtained from Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 8 shows two sharp peaks at 1350 cm−1 and 1590 cm−1, which are attributed to the D and G bands, respectively. The D band at 1350 cm−1 represents the amorphous carbon with structural defects, while the G band at 1590 cm−1 represents the highly ordered graphitic carbon with sp2 in-plane vibration. The intensity ratio of D bands to G bands (I D/I G) can be used to assess the degree of defect in the carbon matrix of the material [42]. After pickling, I D/I G values increase and more structural defects develop, consistent with the SEM characterization in Figs. 3–5. The base strength of the Co-N-C samples was measured by the Hammett indicator method, and the total base content and concentration were measured by a potentiometric titrator (as shown in Table 5 ). The base strength of Co-N-C-CTS is the highest, which is in the range of 15.0 < H < 18.4. In contrast, Co-N-C-DCD and Co-N-C-MLM are in a lower range, both between 7.2 and 9.8. In addition, the total base content of Co-N-C-MLM is much larger than that of Co-N-C-DCD and Co-N-C-CTS. However, the base concentration of Co-N-C-MLM and Co-N-C-DCD is close, and both are larger than that of Co-N-C-CTS. After pickling, the total base content and base concentration of the material will be greatly reduced, and the base strength slides down in the range of 6.8 < H < 7.2. NH3-TPD test was performed to measure the number of acidic sites on Co-N-C-MLM (Fig. 9 A) [17,18]. The peaks shown at comparatively lower temperatures are attributed to weak acidic sites (peak area is 12668.1) while at high temperatures are assigned to strong acidic sites( peak area 7089.2) (Table S3) [17]. Pyridine-FTIR peaks obtained at 350 °C were further recorded to distinguish the types of acidic sites (Fig. 9B). The transmittance peaks centered around 1452 and 1614 cm−1 could be assigned to the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acidic sites, while the peaks centered at 1494 and1630 cm−1 were attributed to the Brønsted acidic sites [43,44]. For the Co-N-C-MLM sample, the peak areas for Lewis acidic sites (16.9 umol/g) were much larger than those for Brønsted acids (2.2 umol/g) (Table S4). 3.2 Knoevenagel reaction 3.2.1 The influence of different catalysts on Knoevenagel reaction Table 6 shows the influence of different Co-N-C materials on the Knoevenagel reaction. Co-N-C-MLM exhibits the highest catalytic activity, with the shortest curing time and the highest product yield (Table 6, entry 1), which may be attributed to its medium base strength (7.2 < H < 9.8), higher cobalt content (48.57 wt.%), highest base content (2.1 mmol g−1), and base concentration (8.7 μmol m−2). Furthermore, Co-N-C-MLM exhibits a shorter reaction time and higher yield than Co-N-C-MLM-H (Table 6, entries 1 and 2), while the samples synthesized from DCD and CTS show similar performance before and after pickling (Table 6, entries 3–6). From the characterization data of ICP-AES, XRD, XPS and the basic properties, it can be seen that a large number of cobalt nanoparticles are washed away by the acid. Since the Lewis acid center Coδ+ is an active site to catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction, the catalytic performance decreases after pickling. On the other hand, Co-N-C-MLM-H exhibits lower catalytic activity than N-C-MLM (Table 6, entries 2 and 8), a similar phenomenon is also shown in the samples synthesized from DCD and CTS (Table 6, entries 4, 6, 9 and 10). For Co-N-C-MLM-H and Co-N-C-DCD-H, the isolated Co2+ combines with nitrogen species such as pyridine nitrogen to form a salt-like structure and the Lewis acid/base catalytic center are lost, resulting in lower catalytic activity than the nitrogen-doped carbon samples (N-C-MLM and N-C-DCD) which have lone pairs of electrons from nitrogen as Lewis base centers. In addition, compared with Co-N-C-CTS and N-C-CTS, the low catalytic activity of Co-N-C-CTS-H can be mainly attributed to the loss of most of the Co2+ and part of the pyridine nitrogen. Moreover, Co-N-C-MLM exhibits a shorter reaction time and higher yield than Co-N-C-MLM-A (Table 6, entries 1 and 7). From the results of elemental analysis, the nitrogen and cobalt contents of multi-step pyrolysis (Co-N-C-MLM) are higher than those of one-step pyrolysis (Co-N-C-MLM-A), thus providing more acid-base sites. Furthermore, Co-C catalyst was also applied to this reaction, which shows lower catalytic activity than Co-N-C-MLM and N-C-MLM (Table 6, entries 1, 8 and 11). And the catalytic activity of N-C-MLM is lower than that of Co-N-C-MLM catalyst (Table 6, entries 1 and 8). On the other hand, pyridine as a homogeneous Lewis base and CoCl2·6H2O as a homogeneous Lewis acid can both effectively catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction (Table 7 , entries 4 and 8). It can be inferred that the Coδ+ species on Co-C and Co-N-C-MLM is a Lewis acidic site, which can catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction. If the distance between the Coδ+ and the lone pair of electrons from a nitrogen species (such as pyridine nitrogen) on the surface of Co-N-C-MLM is appropriate, the Co-N-C-MLM can form an acid-base double active center similar to the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP) of the Coδ+ from cobalt nanoparticles and the Nδ− from nitrogen-contained species. Co ion acts as a Lewis acid site to activate the carbonyl oxygen of the benzaldehyde molecule [19,45], and the N species in carbon acts as a Lewis base site to activate the methylene hydrogen of malononitrile [46], which makes Co-N-C-MLM exhibit higher catalytic activity than N-C-MLM and Co-C. Furthermore, among the homogeneous catalysts, pyridine shows the highest catalytic activity, although the order of base strength is: aniline > pyridine > pyrrole. This indicates that the intermediate-strength base center has a stronger catalytic effect on the reaction, which is consistent with the results of the heterogeneous catalyst. On the other hand, N–C shows 2.5–27 times higher catalytic activity than carbon or carbon-oxygen samples synthesized from glucose (C-GLC), graphite and graphite oxide (Table 6, entries 8–10 and 12–15). Therefore, nitrogen is more likely to become an active center in the Knoevenagel reaction than oxygen and carbon. Furthermore, MLM, DCD and CTS also show catalytic activity of Knoevenagel reaction (Table 6, entries 1–3), which is attributed to the amine group in their molecule. The low catalytic activity of chitosan may be due to the formation of hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl and amino groups, which reduces the base strength of the latter. In conclusion, the Co-N-C-MLM exhibits excellent catalytic performance in catalyzing the Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile, primarily due to the highest contents of the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP) formed from the Coδ+ in the Co nanoparticles and the Nδ− in the nitrogenous species (mainly the pyridine group). Co-N-C is a steric acid-base bifunctional catalyst that can synergistically catalyze Knoevenagel reaction. Furthermore, based on the catalytic effect of the sample formed by one-step pyrolysis and the that formed by multi-step pyrolysis, it can be seen that the multi-step pyrolysis has a shorter reaction time and a higher yield of the target product. 3.2.2 The effect of different solvents on the catalytic performance of Co-N-C-MLM The reactants benzaldehyde and malononitrile are immiscible in water, but these two substances are soluble in a variety of mono alcohols or mixtures of alcohol and water. Table 8 shows the effect of different solvents on the catalytic performance of Co-N-C-MLM for Knoevenagel reaction. When alcohols are used as solvents, the polarity of the solvent and the reaction rate decreases with the increase of molecular weight of the alcohol. When a mixed solvent of ethanol and water (V ethanol: V water = 3:1) is used, Co-N-C-MLM exhibits the best catalytic performance with the shortest reaction time (only 3.4 min) and the highest product yield (90.1%). It may be attributed to the fact that the combined action of non-polar and polar solvents drive the polar groups of benzaldehyde and malononitrile towards the more polar acid-base catalytic active centers on the surface of Co-N-C-MLM and help the desorption of products with weaker polarity than the reactants [10]. Since water has strong polarity [47–49] and alcohols can increase the solubility of reactants, the mixed solvent composed of ethanol and water is favorable to the reaction. 3.2.3 The effect of benzaldehyde concentration on the catalytic performance of Co-N-C-MLM Fig. 10 shows the effect of benzaldehyde concentration on the Knoevenagel reaction. When the concentration of reactant (benzaldehyde) is 6.7 mol/L, the catalytic reaction performance is the best. When the curing time is 3.1 s, the product yield can reach 91.1%. This may be ascribed to the fact that the appropriate reactant concentration helps to reduce the viscosity of the reaction system and increase the rate of contact between the reaction substrates and the catalyst surface. However, when the amount of solvent is too large, the energy consumption in the process of product recovery will increase, thus increasing the recovery cost. 3.2.4 Effects of the mass ratio of benzaldehyde to catalyst The effect of the mass ratio of reactant (benzaldehyde) to Co-N-C-MLM catalyst on the catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 11 . When the mass ratio was reduced from 21.2 to 10.6, the curing time was shortened from 3.1 min to 2.5 min, and the yield was increased from 91.1% to 93.7%. The required curing time slowly decreases and the yield decreases slightly if the mass ratio drops further. Therefore, the optimal mass ratio of benzaldehyde to Co-NC-MLM catalyst is 10.6. 3.2.5 Stability and reusability of Co-N-C catalyst The specific steps of the cyclic reaction are as follows. The solid mixtures obtained from the reaction was fully dissolved in hot ethanol at 80 °C, and then filtered with suction. The solid catalyst obtained was washed three times with ethanol and dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and then continued to be used in the next reaction. There were losses during the catalyst recovery process and the amount of the reactant was adjusted accordingly to maintain a constant reactant-to-catalyst mass ratio. The curing time of the reaction during the 5 cycles of Co-N-C-MLM was unchanged, and the product yield did not decrease significantly (Fig. 12 ), indicating that the synthesized Co-N-C-MLM catalyst is fairly stable in the Knoevenagel reaction (Fig. 13 ). 3.2.6 Effect of substrates To verify the general applicability of Co-N-C-MLM in the Knoevenagel reaction, various aldehyde reactants were used under identical conditions, and the corresponding results are shown in Table 9 . For malononitrile and p-anisaldehyde, 4-cyanobenzaldehyde, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde, p-chlorobenzaldehyde or 2-chlorobenzaldehyde, the Co-N-C-MLM shows better catalytic performance, which indicates that Co-N-C can efficiently catalyze the reaction with different kinds of carbonyl compounds. 3.2.7 Catalytic reaction mechanism In the Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile, the Coδ+ and Nδ− in the Co-N coordination structure acted as the steric Lewis acid-base pairs to adsorb and activate the substrates [19,45]. Coδ+ acts as a Lewis acid site to activate the carbonyl oxygen in benzaldehyde, and the Nδ− species (more precisely the lone electron pair of pyridyl groups) on carbon surface acts as a Lewis base site to activate the methylene hydrogen in malononitrile to form an active methylene group [46]. The activated benzaldehyde is coupled with malononitrile to form benzylidenemalononitrile. Therefore, the reaction efficiency of the acid-base synergistic catalysis is significantly higher than that of basic or acidic catalysis alone. 4 Conclusions Using an easy one-pot method, we obtained various Co-N-C catalysts, which were characterized and used to catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile. The effects of reaction solvent, reactant (benzaldehyde) concentration and the mass ratio of reactant (benzaldehyde) to catalyst (Co-N-C-MLM) on the Knoevenagel reaction are investigated systematically. For the Co-N-C-MLM, the reaction curing time is 2.5 min, and the product yield is as high as 93.7%. This high activity is due to the acid-base synergistic catalysis between steric Coδ+ and Nδ− species (mainly pyridyl nitrogen) of Co-N-C-MLM. The catalysts have excellent stability and recyclability. The Co ion acts as a Lewis acid site to activate the carbonyl oxygen of the benzaldehyde molecule, and the N species in carbon acts as a Lewis base site to activate the methylene hydrogen of malononitrile. The high contents of nitrogen and cobalt in the form of the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP) are the main reason for the excellent performance of the catalysts. From the perspective of intrinsic activity, variation in catalytic properties is a result of the stereoscopic and localized electron density distribution on the catalyst surface. This work may provide some reference for the related heterogeneous acid-base catalytic reactions, especially in the design of steric bifunctional catalysts with Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP). coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen-doped carbon confined cobalt nanoparticles (Co-N-C) were synthesized through multi-step pyrolysis method. The Co-N-C samples exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the Knoevenagel reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile, of which the yield can be as high as 93.7% within 2.5 min with outstanding stability and recyclability. The catalytic performance may be primarily ascribed to the richness in nitrogen and cobalt in the form of the solid Frustrated Lewis Pair (FLP), i.e. the Co ion acts as a Lewis acid site to activate the carbonyl oxygen of benzaldehyde molecules, and nitrogen in carbon acts as a Lewis base site to activate the methylene hydrogen of malononitrile. From the perspective of intrinsic catalytic activity, variations in catalytic properties are attributed to the electron density distribution on the surface of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen-doped carbon confined cobalt nanoparticles as the steric acid-base multifunctional catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation
